# Understand Firebase for Android Stay organized with collections Save and categorize content based on your preferences.
As you're developing your Android project using Firebase, you might discover
concepts that are unfamiliar or specific to Firebase. This page aims to answer
those questions or point you to resources to learn more.

If you have questions about a topic not covered on this page, feel free to visit
one of our [online communities](https://firebase.google.com/community#join-the-discussion). We'll also
update this page with new topics periodically, so check back to see if we've
added the topic you want to learn about!

## Firebase Assistant plugin for Android Studio
The Firebase Assistant is an Android Studio plugin that registers your Android
app with a Firebase project and adds the necessary Firebase config files,
plugins, and dependencies to your Android project â€” all from within Android
Studio!

Follow the instructions in the
[Android getting started page](https://firebase.google.com/docs/android/setup#assistant) to use the
Firebase Assistant. Make sure that you're using the most up-to-date versions of
both Android Studio and the Firebase Assistant
(go to **File > Check for updates**).

When you select specific Firebase products to add to your app, the Firebase
Assistant automatically declares the required dependencies in your
`app/build.gradle` file. Note that if you want to use the
[Firebase Android BoM](https://firebase.google.com/firebase.google.com#bom) _(recommended)_, update the dependencies in your
**module (app-level) Gradle file** (usually `app/build.gradle`) to import the
BoM platform. You'll also need to remove the versions from each Firebase
library dependency line.

Additionally, to use some Firebase products, you must enable APIs or provision
resources outside of Android Studio. The instructions for each product in the
Firebase Assistant describe any additional actions that you need to do. For
example, to use Cloud Firestore, you need to set up your database and rules in the
Firebase console.

## Google services â€” plugin and config file
As part of adding Firebase to your Android project, you need to add the
`google-services` plugin and a `google-services.json` configuration file to
your project.

If you add Firebase to your Android project via
the [Firebase console](https://firebase.google.com/docs/android/setup#console),
the [Management REST API](https://firebase.google.com/docs/projects/api/workflow_set-up-and-manage-project?platform=android#add-apps),
or the [Firebase CLI](https://firebase.google.com/docs/cli#management-commands),
you must manually add the plugin and config file to your project. However, if
you use the [Firebase Assistant](https://firebase.google.com/firebase.google.com#firebase-assistant), these tasks are
automatically done for you during setup.

Visit the
[Android documentation](https://developers.google.com/android/guides/google-services-plugin)
to learn about how the Google services plugin and config file work together.

## Firebase Android BoM (Bill of Materials)
The Firebase Android BoM (Bill of Materials) lets you manage all your
Firebase library versions by specifying only one version â€” the BoM's
version.

When you use the Firebase BoM in your app, the BoM automatically pulls
in the individual library versions mapped to BoM's version. **All the**
**individual library versions will be compatible.** When you update the BoM's
version in your app, all the Firebase libraries that you use in your app will
update to the versions mapped to that BoM version.

To learn which Firebase library versions are mapped to a specific BoM
version, check out the [release notes](https://firebase.google.com/support/release-notes/android) for that
BoM version. If you need to compare the library versions mapped to one
BoM version compared to another BoM version, use the
[comparison widget](https://firebase.google.com/firebase.google.com#compare-bom-versions) below.

Learn more about [Gradle's support for BoM platforms](https://docs.gradle.org/4.6-rc-1/userguide/managing_transitive_dependencies.html#sec:bom_import).

Here's how to use the Firebase Android BoM to declare dependencies in your
**module (app-level) Gradle file** (usually `app/build.gradle`). When using the
BoM, you don't specify individual library versions in the dependency lines.

```
dependencies{
// Import the BoM for the Firebase platform
implementationplatform('com.google.firebase:firebase-bom:34.2.0')

// Declare the dependencies for the desired Firebase products without specifying versions
// For example, declare the dependencies for Firebase Authentication and Cloud Firestore
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-auth'
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-firestore'
}
```

Here are some frequently asked questions about using the Firebase Android BoM:

How do I use a _different_ library version than what's designated in
the BoM?

Here's how to override a library version designated in the BoM:

1. Maintain the line to import the BoM platform.

2. In the library's dependency line, specify the desired library version. For
example, here's how to declare dependencies if you want to use v18.0.0
of App Indexing no matter what version is designated in the BoM,
_**but**_ you want to use the BoM's versions for
Authentication and Cloud Firestore:


```
dependencies{
// Import the BoM for the Firebase platform
implementationplatform('com.google.firebase:firebase-bom:34.2.0')

// Declare the dependency for the App Indexing library and specify a version
// This specified library version overrides the version designated in the BoM.
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-appindexing:18.0.0'

// Declare the dependencies for the other Firebase libraries without specifying versions
// These libraries will use the versions designated in the BoM.
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-auth'
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-firestore'
}
```


Does the BoM automatically add all the Firebase libraries to my app?

No. To actually add and use Firebase libraries in your app, you must declare
each library as a separate dependency line in your **module (app-level) Gradle**
**file** (usually `app/build.gradle`).

Using the BoM ensures that the _versions_ of any Firebase libraries in your
app are compatible, but the BoM doesn't actually _add_ those Firebase
libraries to your app.

Are the Firebase Kotlin extensions (KTX) libraries supported by the BoM?

In July 2025 (BoM v34.0.0), the Firebase Kotlin extensions (KTX) libraries
were removed from the BoM. If you use a BoM version earlier than
v34.0.0, then you can continue using KTX libraries in your app.

However, we recommend that you migrate your app to use KTX APIs from the main
modules; otherwise, you won't be able to update to newer BoM versions and
thus newer versions of the Firebase product libraries. For details, see the
[FAQ about this initiative](https://firebase.google.com/docs/android/kotlin-migration).


## Firebase Android BoM (Bill of Materials)

Can I use the BoM to add Android libraries that are _not_ from
Firebase?

No. The Firebase Android BoM only manages library versions for Firebase
libraries.

Why is the BoM the recommended way to manage Firebase library versions?

Even though each Firebase library is versioned independently, they are built
together to ensure that the latest release of each library is compatible with
the others.

By using the BoM to manage your app's Firebase library versions, you don't
need to track which version of a Firebase library is compatible with another
Firebase library.

Even if you only use one Firebase library in your app right now, we still
recommend using the BoM because you never know when you might want to use
another Firebase library!

My app uses a Gradle version _earlier than 5.0_ â€” can I still use the
BoM?

Yes, you can still use the BoM! For Gradle 5.0 and later, BoM support is
automatically enabled. However, **for earlier versions of Gradle,**
you just need to
[enable the BoM feature](https://docs.gradle.org/4.6-rc-1/release-notes.html)
and import the BoM a bit differently.

1. To your `settings.gradle` file, add
`enableFeaturePreview('IMPROVED_POM_SUPPORT')`.

2. To your **module (app-level) Gradle file** (usually
`app/build.gradle`), import the BoM like a normal library (without the
`platform` modifier), like so:


```
dependencies{
// Import the Firebase BoM
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-bom:34.2.0'

// Declare the dependencies for the desired Firebase products, without specifying versions
// For example, declare the dependencies for Firebase Authentication and Cloud Firestore
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-auth'
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-firestore'
}
```


How do I report an issue or offer feedback on the BoM?

Visit the
[Firebase Android SDK repo on GitHub](https://github.com/firebase/firebase-android-sdk/issues).

## Feature modules and Play Feature Delivery
As of May 2021 (Firebase BoM v28.0.0), Firebase Android SDKs can be
used in dynamic feature modules which are installed separately from your base
application module.

To enable support for dynamic feature modules, add the following dependency
to your **base** module's `build.gradle` file:

```
dependencies{
implementation'com.google.firebase:firebase-dynamic-module-support:16.0.0-beta04'
}
```

Now that you've added dynamic module support, you can add Firebase SDK
dependencies (with or without the Firebase BoM) to feature modules of your
app and use them as you normally would.

For example, if your application uses Realtime Database to power a specific realtime
feature you could add the `firebase-database` dependency to the `build.gradle`
of the feature module rather than the base module. This will reduce download
size for most users.

Be aware of the following caveats when using Firebase SDKs in feature modules:

- Products such as Dynamic Links or Firebase In-App Messaging which rely on the Analytics `first_open` event may miss this event when used in a dynamic feature module.

- When using Cloud Firestore and Authentication together, you should always include them
both in the same module. If this is not possible, then make sure that Authentication
is loaded _before_ Cloud Firestore; otherwise, some Cloud Firestore operations may
have an incorrect authentication state.

- When using `firebase-crashlytics-ndk` as a dependency of a dynamic feature
module, you need to set the `unstrippedNativeLibsDir` property in your app's
`build.gradle` file, as described in the
[Crashlytics NDK documentation](https://firebase.google.com/docs/crashlytics/ndk-reports#upload-external-dependencies).


For more information on feature modules and Play Feature Delivery, visit
[Overview of Play Feature Delivery](https://developer.android.com/guide/playcore/feature-delivery).

## Google services Gradle plugin vs Google Play services vs Google Play Store
Several pieces of the Google, Firebase, and Android ecosystem have similar
naming conventions. Here's a brief explanation for each:

Google services Gradle pluginA Gradle plugin ( `com.google.gms.google-services`) that runs at build time to
ensure that your app has the right configuration to access Firebase and Google
APIsDespite its name, this plugin has no relation to Google Play services (see
next entry) and has no impact on your app's capabilities at runtime.This plugin also processes the `google-services.json` file that you add to
your app as part of setting up Firebase. Learn more about the
[Google services Gradle plugin](https://firebase.google.com/docs/android/learn-more#google-services-plugin-and-file).Google Play servicesAn invisible background service that runs on an Android device and provides
several common Google APIs (like Google Maps and Google Sign In) to apps on
the deviceBy centralizing these common APIs into a single service, it reduces the size
of other apps and allows a device to receive automatic security updates and
feature enhancements without an OS update. Learn more about
[Google Play services](https://developers.google.com/android/guides/overview).Google Play StoreA store to download apps, movies, books, and more on an Android deviceAs a developer, you manage the distribution, releases, etc. for your app via
the Google Play Console. If a device has the Google Play Store, it's also
running Google Play services (see previous entry). Learn more about the
[Google Play Store for developers](https://developer.android.com/distribute).Google Play Games servicesA set of APIs for mobile game developersLearn more about
[Google Play Games services](https://developers.google.com/games/services)
and how to
[integrate Firebase with your Google Play Games services project](https://firebase.google.com/support/guides/integrate-play-games).

## Open source resources for Firebase Android SDKs
Firebase supports open source development, and we encourage community
contributions and feedback.

### Firebase Android SDKs
Most Firebase Android SDKs are developed as open source libraries in our public
[Firebase GitHub repository](https://github.com/firebase/firebase-android-sdk).
We're actively working to move the remaining privately developed Firebase
libraries to our public GitHub soon!

### Quickstart samples
Firebase maintains a collection of quickstart samples for most Firebase APIs on
Android. Find these quickstarts in our public
[Firebase GitHub quickstart repository](https://github.com/firebase/quickstart-android).

You can open each quickstart as an Android Studio project, then run them on a
mobile device or a virtual device (AVD). Or you can use these quickstarts as
example code for using Firebase SDKs.

## April 14, 2025
- The latest update of `play-services-maps` (v19.2.0) includes improvements for
attribution.

- The latest updates to the `play-services-base`, `play-services-basement`, and
`play-services-tasks` libraries include the following changes:

 - Added an `aar-metadata.properties` file inside each AAR, which enforces the
 following:

 - Your app must be built with Android Gradle Plugin (AGP) v8.2.0 or higher.

 - Your app must set `isCoreLibraryDesugaringEnabled = true`. Learn how to
 [enable Java 8+ API desugaring support](https://developer.android.com/studio/write/java8-support#library-desugaring).

 - Setting `isCoreLibraryDesugaringEnabled = true` is desirable because
 subsequent releases of Play services libraries may start referring to
 language APIs that are only available in recent Android releases.
 Without library desugaring, your app may encounter runtime errors
 (such as `NoClassDefFoundError` and `NoSuchMethodError`) on older
 platform versions.

 - If you desire to opt out of library desugaring enforcement, see
 [options](https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/413427422#comment3).

 [`setAttestationFormats`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/PublicKeyCredentialCreationOptions.Builder#setAttestationFormats(java.util.List%3Cjava.lang.String%3E))

 - Added a new API
 [`setPaymentExtension`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/AuthenticationExtensions.Builder#setPaymentExtension(com.google.android.gms.fido.fido2.api.common.PaymentExtension))

- The latest updates to the `play-services-base`, `play-services-basement`, and
`play-services-tasks` libraries include the following changes:

 and
 [`useBackgroundThreadForConnectionCallback`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/GooglePlayServicesUtil#useBackgroundThreadForConnectionCallback())

 services.
 - Added the
 [`isUsingBackgroundThreadExecutorForBindService`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/GooglePlayServicesUtil#isUsingBackgroundThreadExecutorForBindService())
 method to get the current opt-in state of using a background thread
 executor.
 - Artifacts are now published with accompanying `.asc` signature files to
 ensure authenticity. Optionally, you can
 [enable signature verification](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/dependency_verification.html).
 See the
 [Jetpack documentation to configure Google's trusted keys](https://developer.android.com/jetpack/getting-started#verify_dependencies).

## February 24, 2025
- Updates the Google Mobile Ads Android SDK.
For more information, refer to the product
[release notes](https://developers.google.com/admob/android/rel-notes#24.0.0).

- The Firebase Ads SDKs (the `firebase-ads` and `firebase-ads-lite` artifacts)
are no longer being published. Instead, use the Google Mobile Ads Android SDK.
For some apps, you _might_ also need to add the
Firebase SDK for Google Analytics.

The `firebase-ads` and `firebase-ads-lite` artifacts did not supply their own
binary and were only a wrapper around their dependencies. We're making this
change to give you more control over the dependencies that you add to your
app. For more information about this change and how to migrate to use the
Google Mobile Ads Android SDK, see
[this FAQ](https://firebase.google.com/support/faq#admob-which-sdk) in the
Firebase documentation.

Note that _**any existing versions will continue to work**_. However, to get
bug fixes and new features, you'll need to migrate to use the SDKs as
described in the
[FAQ](https://firebase.google.com/support/faq#admob-which-sdk).

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-ads:24.0.0
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-ads-lite:24.0.0

## December 17, 2024
- The latest update to the Credential Manager APIs
( `play-services-identity-credentials`) includes the following changes:

 - Added the
 [create credential API](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/IdentityCredentialClient#createCredential(com.google.android.gms.identitycredentials.CreateCredentialRequest)),
 supported through the
 [`CreateCredentialRequest`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/kotlin/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/CreateCredentialRequest),
 the [`CreateCredentialResponse`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/CreateCredentialResponse),
 the [`CreateCredentialHandle`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/kotlin/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/CreateCredentialHandle),
 and the [`CreateCredentialException`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/kotlin/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/CreateCredentialException).
 - Added the
 [`CredentialProviderService`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/provider/CredentialProviderService)
 for providers to receive credential updates.
 - Added the
 [`CallingAppInfoParcelable`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/kotlin/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/CallingAppInfoParcelable)
 class to propagate the client information to credential providers.
 - Added the
 [`CreateCredentialCallback`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/kotlin/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/provider/CreateCredentialCallback)
 class for providers to propagate the credential creation response back to
 the clients.
 - Added
 [support for specifying a different intent action](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/kotlin/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/RegistrationRequest#fulfillmentActionName())
 to be used for launching the fulfillment activity when a registered
 credential is selected by the user.
 - Add support for storing / provisioning credentials through the registry,
 through the
 [`RegisterCreationOptionsRequest`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/RegisterCreationOptionsRequest)
 and the
 [`RegisterCreationOptionsResponse`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/identitycredentials/RegisterCreationOptionsResponse)

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-identity-credentials:16.0.0-alpha04

## December 10, 2024
- The latest update to the `play-services-time` library includes the following
changes:

 - Introduced the initial public stable release of the
 [`TrustedTimeClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/time/TrustedTimeClient).
 `TrustedTimeClient` provides methods that can be used as alternatives to
 `System.currentTimeMillis()` and `Instant.now()` that cannot be affected by
 end users. Additionally, the `TrustedTimeClient` offers information about
 accuracy bounds for the returned time.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-time:16.0.0

## December 09, 2024
- The latest update to `play-services-ads-identifier` (v18.2.0) includes the
following change:

 - Created a shared persistent client rather than making a one-off binding for
 each ad ID call. This lowers the latency. The client will auto-disconnect
 after being idle for 30 seconds.
- The latest update to the `play-services-auth` library (v21.3.0) includes the
following changes:

 - Added a new API
 [`setOptOutOfIncludeGrantedScopes`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/AuthorizationRequest.Builder#setOptOutIncludingGrantedScopes(boolean))
 to
 [`AuthorizationRequest.Builder`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/AuthorizationRequest.Builder),
 which specifies if previously granted scopes should be skipped.

 - Deprecated
 [`GoogleAuthUtil.clearToken`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/GoogleAuthUtil#public-static-void-cleartoken-context-context,-string-token).

 - Deprecated all APIs for getting tokens. To fetch access tokens for
 authorization, use
 [`AuthorizationClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/AuthorizationClient).
 To fetch identity tokens for authentication use
 [Credential Manager](https://developer.android.com/identity/sign-in/credential-manager-siwg)
 instead.
- The latest update of the Google Play services LiteRT (TensorFlow Lite)
library (v16.4.0) is now available. New in this release is beta support
for the LiteRT (TF Lite) C++ API.

This library can be used as an alternative to the standalone
LiteRT (TensorFlow Lite) library to reduce app size and receive automatic
updates. For more information, refer to the
[LiteRT documentation](http://www.tensorflow.org/lite/android/play_services).

The latest updates to the Google Play services TensorFlow Lite libraries
include all the changes included in the v2.18.0 release of TensorFlow
Lite.

## June 25, 2024
- The latest updates to `play-services-maps` (v19.0.0) include support for the
following new features:


 - Configuring map color scheme to dark, light, or to use system settings.
 For details, see
 [Configure a map](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/configure-map).
 - Use of default colors for maps to match the new colors that are already
 available in the Google Maps app. For details, see
 [New map style for Google Maps Platform](https://developers.google.com/maps/new-map-style-opt-in).
 - Use of
 [data-driven styling for boundaries](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/dds-boundaries/overview)
 and
 [data-driven styling for datasets](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/dds-datasets/overview).

The latest version of `play-services-maps` also includes the following API
updates:

 - Added [`DatasetFeature`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/DatasetFeature).
 - Added [`Feature`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/Feature).
 - Added [`FeatureClickEvent`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/FeatureClickEvent).
 - Added [`FeatureLayer`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/FeatureLayer).
 - Added [`FeatureLayerOptions`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/FeatureLayerOptions).
 - Added [`FeatureStyle`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/FeatureStyle).
 - Added [`FeatureType`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/FeatureType).
 - Added [`MapColorScheme`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/MapColorScheme).
 - Added [`PlaceFeature`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/PlaceFeature).
 - Deprecated `MapsInitializer.Renderer.LEGACY` in
 [`MapsInitializer.Renderer`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/MapsInitializer.Renderer).
 Instead, use the
 [latest map renderer](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/renderer).
 - Updated [`MapCapabilities`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/MapCapabilities)
 to include methods for checking availability for data-driven styling.
 - Updated [`GoogleMap`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/GoogleMap)
 to include methods for setting map color scheme.
 - Updated [`GoogleMapOptions`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/GoogleMapOptions)
 to include methods for setting map color scheme.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-maps:19.0.0

## June 04, 2024
- The `play-services-appsearch` library is now generally available. This
library provides APIs to store structured data in the centralized AppSearch
database provided by Google Play services. This enables cross-app data sharing
based on the client-provided access control list (ACL) configuration.
Cross-app sharing is opt-in and requires explicit developer configuration when
using AppSearch APIs.

- The latest update to the `play-services-cloud-messaging` library includes
the following changes:

 - Added a new method,
 [`setRetainProxiedNotifications`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cloudmessaging/Rpc#setRetainProxiedNotifications(boolean)),
 to set whether to retain data for notifications that are proxied.
 - Added a new method,
 [`getProxiedNotificationData`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cloudmessaging/Rpc#getProxiedNotificationData()),
 to get data for a notification that was proxied.

## April 16, 2024
- The latest update to the `play-services-auth` library includes the following
changes:

 - Deprecated the APIs related to the One Tap Sign-in, Password Saving, and
 Sign-in with Google button.
- The latest update to the `play-services-base` library includes the following
changes:

 - Deprecated the APIs related to Google Sign-in.
- The latest update to the `play-services-fido` library includes the following
changes:

 - Updated the request and response data class to be backed by `ByteString`
 instead of `byte[]` so that they are immutable.
 - Added proper `@Nullable` and `@NonNull` annotations to API parameters.
 - Added a new constructor to
 [`PublicKeyCredentialCreationOptions`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/PublicKeyCredentialCreationOptions)
 that accepts a JSON string.

## March 07, 2024
- Updates the Google Mobile Ads Android SDK and Firebase Ads SDK.
For more information, refer to the product
[release notes](https://developers.google.com/admob/android/rel-notes#23.0.0).

- In September 2024, the Firebase Ads SDKs (the `firebase-ads` and
`firebase-ads-lite` artifacts) will no longer be published. Instead, use
the Google Mobile Ads Android SDK.

These Firebase artifacts did not supply their own binary and were only a
wrapper around their dependencies. We're making this change to give you more
control over the dependencies that you add to your app. For more information
about this change and how to migrate to use the Google Mobile Ads Android SDK,
see
[this FAQ](https://firebase.google.com/support/faq#admob-which-sdk) in the
Firebase documentation.

Notes](https://firebase.google.com/support/release-notes/android#2024-03-07).

## February 26, 2024
- The latest update to the `play-services-wallet` library includes the
following changes:


 - Added new contracts that can be used with the new Activity Result API on
 Android to handle
 [`loadPaymentData`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/wallet/PaymentsClient#loadPaymentData(com.google.android.gms.wallet.PaymentDataRequest))
 task results. To learn more, see the
 [Google Pay Android SDK Release Notes](https://developers.google.com/pay/api/android/support/release-notes#feb-24).

 - Deprecated
 [`AutoResolveHelper#resolveTask(Task, Activity, int)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/wallet/AutoResolveHelper#resolveTask(com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task%3CTResult%3E,%20android.app.Activity,%20int)).
 Use the [new Activity Result API contracts](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/wallet/contract/TaskResultContracts) introduced in this release instead.


Note that these changes were made available in
[`play-services-wallet` v19.3.0-beta01](https://developers.google.com/developers.google.com#december_14_2023).

## January 04, 2024
- The latest updates to the `play-services-base`, `play-services-basement`, and
`play-services-tasks` libraries include the following changes:

 - Added a new overloaded method
 [`startResolutionForResult`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/api/Status#startResolutionForResult(androidx.activity.result.ActivityResultLauncher%3Candroidx.activity.result.IntentSenderRequest%3E))
 that uses AndroidX `ActivityResultContract`.

 - Added new overloaded methods enabling more flexibility with custom
 executors:

 - [`whenAllComplete(java.util.concurrent.Executor, java.util.Collection)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks#whenAllComplete(java.util.concurrent.Executor,java.util.Collection%3C?%20extends%20com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task%3C?%3E%3E))

 - [`whenAllComplete(java.util.concurrent.Executor, com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task[])`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks#whenAllComplete(java.util.concurrent.Executor,com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task%3C?%3E...))

 - [`whenAllSuccess(java.util.concurrent.Executor, java.util.Collection)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks#whenAllSuccess(java.util.concurrent.Executor,java.util.Collection%3C?%20extends%20com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task%3C?%3E%3E))

 - [`whenAllSuccess(java.util.concurrent.Executor, com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task[])`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks#whenAllSuccess(java.util.concurrent.Executor,com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task%3C?%3E...))

## December 26, 2023
- The latest update to the Nearby SDK ( `play-services-nearby`) includes
the following changes:

 - Added additional support for the
 [Google Fast Pair Service (GFPS)](https://developers.google.com/nearby/fast-pair/landing-page):

 - Added a new method
 [`getFastPairClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/Nearby#getFastPairClient(android.content.Context)) for
 [`Nearby`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/Nearby)
 to get `FastPairClient`.

 - Added a new class
 [`FastPairClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/fastpair/FastPairClient)
 which contains the APIs related to Fast Pair.

 - Added new methods
 [`isSassDeviceAvailable`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/fastpair/FastPairClient#isSassDeviceAvailable(int)) and
 [`triggerSassForUsage`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/fastpair/FastPairClient#triggerSassForUsage(int)) for
 [`FastPairClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/fastpair/FastPairClient)
 to support
 [Audio Switch](https://developers.google.com/nearby/fast-pair/specifications/extensions/sass).
 - Changed the return type of
 [`supportedSlotDurations`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getSupportedSlotDurations()) and
 [`supportedRangingIntervals`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getSupportedRangingIntervals())
 to `List`.

 - Removed APIs associated with exposure notification.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-nearby:19.1.0

## December 04, 2023
- The latest updates to the `play-services-cast`,
`play-services-cast-framework`, and `play-services-cast-tv` libraries
include the following changes:


 - Updated to depend on `androidx.mediarouter:mediarouter:1.6.0-beta01`. This
 change makes
 [`MediaRouteButtons`](https://developer.android.com/reference/androidx/mediarouter/app/MediaRouteButton)
 always visible by default.

 - Changed to decrease the scenarios where Cast device discovery starts
 automatically without user action.

 - Added
 [`CastOptions.Builder#setSessionTransferEnabled`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastOptions.Builder#setSessionTransferEnabled(boolean))
 to set whether the sender application should display Cast devices when the
 [Output Switcher](https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/android_sender/output_switcher)
 is enabled. The default value is `true`.

 - Added new versions of
 [`CastButtonFactory#setUpMediaRouteButton`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastButtonFactory#public-static-taskvoid-setupmediaroutebutton-context-context,-executor-executor,-mediaroutebutton-button)
 that return
 [`Tasks`](https://developer.android.com/reference/com/google/android/play/core/tasks/Task)
 that apps can listen to for a success or a thrown exception.


For more information, see the
[Cast Android Sender SDK Release Notes](https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/release-notes).

- com.google.android.gms:play-services-cast:21.4.0

## November 16, 2023
- The latest update to Firebase includes changes to:


 - Firebase Android BoM (Bill of Materials)
 - Firebase Authentication
 - Firebase Crashlytics
 - Firebase Performance Monitoring
 - Firebase Remote Config

For more information, see the [Firebase Android SDK Release\
Notes](https://firebase.google.com/support/release-notes/android#2023-11-16).

- The latest update to the `play-services-pay` library (v16.4.0) includes the
following changes to support the e-money features:

 - Added
 [`EmoneyReadiness`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/pay/EmoneyReadiness).

 - Added
 [`EmoneyReadinessStatus`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/pay/EmoneyReadinessStatus).

 - Added a new method
 [`checkReadinessForEmoney`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/pay/PayClient#public-abstract-taskemoneyreadiness-checkreadinessforemoney-string-serviceprovider,-string-accountname)
 for apps on the allowlist for e-money features to check Google Play
 services readiness for e-money support.

 - Added a new method
 [`notifyEmoneyCardStatusUpdate`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/pay/PayClient#public-abstract-taskvoid-notifyemoneycardstatusupdate-string-json)
 for apps on the allowlist for e-money features to notify Google Play
 services of certain e-money card status updates.

 - Added a new method
 [`pushEmoneyCard`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/pay/PayClient#public-abstract-taskvoid-pushemoneycard-string-json,-activityresultlauncherintentsenderrequest-activityresultlauncher)
 for apps on the allowlist for e-money features to push e-money cards to
 Google Play services.

## October 16, 2023
- The latest updates to `play-services-maps` (v18.2.0) include
[Advanced Marker](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/advanced-markers/overview),
and the ability to check map capabilities. Usage of map capabilities is covered
in the two linked guides.

 - Added [`AdvancedMarkerOptions`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/AdvancedMarkerOptions),
 which is used to define options for `AdvancedMarker`.
 - Added [`AdvancedMarker`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/AdvancedMarker)
 - Added [`PinConfig`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/PinConfig)
 - Added [`Glyph`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/PinConfig.Glyph)
 - Added [`MapCapabilities`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/MapCapabilities)
 - Updated [`GoogleMap`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/GoogleMap)
 to include methods for getting `MapCapabilities`, and listen for changes in
 `MapCapabilities`

## September 25, 2023
- The latest update to the Nearby SDK ( `play-services-nearby`) includes
the following changes:

 - Added a new method,
 [`addControleeWithSessionParams`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/UwbClient#addControleeWithSessionParams),
 for
 [`UwbClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/UwbClient)
 to support Provisioned STS individual key case.

 - Added new methods,
 [`reconfigureRangingInterval`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/UwbClient#reconfigureRangingInterval)
 and
 [`reconfigureRangeDataNtf`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/UwbClient#reconfigureRangeDataNtf),
 for
 [`UwbClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/UwbClient)
 to support dynamic reconfiguration of ranging interval and range data
 notification.

 - Added new ranging capabilities for configurable slot durations and
 ranging intervals. See
 [`supportedSlotDurations`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getSupportedSlotDurations()),
 [`supportedRangingIntervals`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getSupportedRangingIntervals()),
 [`supportsRangingIntervalReconfigure`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#supportsRangingIntervalReconfigure()),
 and
 [`hasBackgroundRangingSupport`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#hasBackgroundRangingSupport()).

 - Added new ranging parameters to configure slot duration,
 ranging interval, and AoA. See
 [`slotDuration`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingParameters#getSlotDuration()),
 [`rangingInterval`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingParameters#getRangingInterval()),
 and
 [`isAoaDisabled`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingParameters#isAoaDisabled).

 - Added [`getAuthenticationStatus`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionInfo#getAuthenticationStatus())
 to get authentication status and
 [`ConnectionInfo.Builder#setAuthenticationStatus`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionInfo.Builder)
 to set authentication handshaking result.

 - Removed the APIs in Nearby Presence. No replacement is available.

 - Deprecated the APIs in Nearby Messages. Use
 [`ConnectionsClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionsClient)
 instead.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-nearby:19.0.0

## February 28, 2023
- The latest update to the Block Store library ( `play-services-auth-blockstore`)
includes the following changes:

 - Added a new method
 [`StoreBytesData.Builder#setKey`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/blockstore/StoreBytesData.Builder),
 to associate the data with a key.

 - Added a new API for
 [`BlockstoreClient#retrieveBytes(RetrieveBytesRequest)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/blockstore/BlockstoreClient)
 with additional request options.

 - Added a new API for
 [`BlockstoreClient#deleteBytes(DeleteBytesRequest)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/blockstore/BlockstoreClient)
 with additional request options.

 - Added a new constants variable
 [`BlockstoreClient#DEFAULT_BYTES_DATA_KEY(DEFAULT_BYTES_DATA_KEY)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/blockstore/BlockstoreClient),
 which can be used when a key has not been specified.

 - Deprecated
 [`BlockstoreClient#retrieveBytes()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/blockstore/BlockstoreClient#retrieveBytes()),
 in favor of
 [`BlockstoreClient#retrieveBytes(RetrieveBytesRequest)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/blockstore/BlockstoreClient#retrieveBytes(RetrieveBytesRequest)).

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-auth-blockstore:16.2.0

## February 01, 2023
- The latest update to Nearby UWB SDK includes the following changes:

 - Added new ranging capabilities to show the capacities of a device:
 - [`minRangingInterval`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getMinRangingInterval())
 - [`supportedChannels`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getSupportedChannels())
 - [`supportedConfigIds`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingCapabilities#getSupportedConfigIds())

 - Added new ranging parameters to support Provisioned-STS ranging:

 - [`subSessionId`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingParameters#getSubSessionId())

 - [`subSessionKeyInfo`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingParameters#getSubSessionKeyInfo())

 - Enabled RSSI in ranging position:

 - [`rssi`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/uwb/RangingPosition#getRssiDbm())

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-nearby:18.4.0

## November 17, 2022
- The latest update to the `play-services-auth` library includes the following
changes:

 - Added a new API in [`BeginSignInRequest`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/BeginSignInRequest)
 that enables developers to use [JetPack](https://developer.android.com/jetpack) libraries to use passkeys.
 - Added a new API in [`CredentialSavingClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/CredentialSavingClient) that allows developers to retrieve a status object from the activity result intent.
- The latest update to the `play-services-fido` library includes the following
changes:

 - Introduced
 [`FidoCredentialDetails`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/FidoCredentialDetails).
 - Introduced
 [`GoogleThirdPartyPaymentExtension`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/GoogleThirdPartyPaymentExtension).
 - Introduced
 [`DevicePublicKeyStringDef`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/DevicePublicKeyStringDef).
- The latest update to Firebase includes changes to:


 - Firebase Android BoM (Bill of Materials)

 - Firebase Performance Monitoring

## October 13, 2022
- The latest update to the `play-services-location` library includes the
following changes:

 - [`FusedLocationProviderClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/FusedLocationProviderClient),
 [`ActivityRecognitionClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/ActivityRecognitionClient),
 [`GeofencingClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/GeofencingClient)
 and
 [`SettingsClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/SettingsClient)
 are now interfaces instead of classes, which helps enforce correct usage and
 improves testability.
 - Added
 [`LocationRequest.Builder`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/LocationRequest.Builder)
 class as the preferred method of constructing `LocationRequest`, and
 deprecated old methods of construction.
 - [`CurrentLocationRequest.Builder`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/CurrentLocationRequest.Builder)
 and
 [`LastLocationRequest.Builder`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/LastLocationRequest.Builder)
 are now `final`.
 - `PendingIntent` based APIs invoked by instant apps will now correctly fail
 instead of never delivering results.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-location:21.0.0

## September 20, 2022
- The latest update to the Wearable library includes the following changes:


 - Improved availability for Wearable SDK on devices with Google Play services.
 - Added support for applications targeting Android 13.
 - Replaced `@RecentlyNonNull` and `@RecentlyNullable` with strict nullability
 annotations ( `@NonNull` and `@Nullable`). With this change, what once caused
 a nullness warning will now cause an error when building Kotlin code or
 using Java `null` checking frameworks.

For more information, refer to the
[Wearable release notes](https://developer.android.com/wear/releases).

- Updates the Google Play services ML Kit libraries. For more information,
refer to the [ML Kit release notes](https://developers.google.com/ml-kit/release-notes#september_20_2022).

## August 08, 2022
- Updates to the `play-services-cast`, `play-services-cast-framework`, and
`play-services-cast-tv` libraries include:


 - Deprecated [`CastContext#getSharedInstance(Context)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastContext#getSharedInstance(android.content.Context)).
 Instead, use [`CastContext#getSharedInstance(Context, Executor)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastContext#getSharedInstance(android.content.Context,%20java.util.concurrent.Executor)),
 which returns a Task API, and
 [`ModuleUnavailableException`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/ModuleUnavailableException)
 for handling the exception when the Cast SDK fails to load the internal
 Cast module.
 - Deprecated [`ApplicationMetadata#getImages()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/ApplicationMetadata#getImages()).
 Instead, use
 [`ApplicationMetadata#getIconUrl()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/ApplicationMetadata#getIconUrl())
 which returns the application image that is set in the Cast Developer
 Console.
 - Changed the `minSdkVersion` from 14 to 16 for the `play-services-cast-tv`
 library.

For more information, see the
[Cast Android Sender SDK Release Notes](https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/release-notes).

## July 18, 2022
- The latest updates to `play-services-maps` include advanced
[polyline customizations](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/shapes#polyline-customization)
for general availability, specifically the following:

 - Added [style span to polyline](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/Polyline).
 - Added [sprite style](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/SpriteStyle).
 - Added [texture style](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/maps/model/TextureStyle).
- The latest update to Nearby UWB SDK includes the following changes:

 - Enabled UWB controller client creation.
 - Enabled one-to-many double-sided two-way ranging (DS-TWR).
- The latest update to the Nearby Connections SDK includes the following
changes:

 - Added
 [`ConnectionLifecycleCallback#onBandwidthChanged`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionLifecycleCallback#onBandwidthChanged(java.lang.String,%20com.google.android.gms.nearby.connection.BandwidthInfo))
 to notify the client that the connection quality is good (6 ~ 60 MBps),
 ok (60 ~ 200 KBps), or poor (5 KBps).
 - Added
 [`ConnectionType`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionType)
 to replace the original API (for example, use
 [`AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setConnectionType`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setConnectionType)
 instead of
 [`AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean)).
 - Deprecated
 [`AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean)).
 Use [`AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setConnectionType`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setConnectionType)
 instead.
 - Deprecated
 [`ConnectionOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean)).
 Use [`ConnectionOptions.Builder#setConnectionType`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionOptions.Builder#setConnectionType)
 instead.

 interface that indicates whether an API requires an additional Google
 Play services component (that is, an optional module).

 [`ModuleInstallClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/moduleinstall/ModuleInstallClient)

 modules, to release optional modules, and to check the availability of
 APIs that require optional modules.

available. It provides testing fakes for
[`ModuleInstallClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/moduleinstall/ModuleInstallClient).

## June 07, 2022
- The latest update to the `play-services-location` library includes the
following changes:

 - Fixed
 [nullability annotation issues](https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/210747276)
 for Kotlin clients.
 - Fixed `LocationCallback` [memory leak issue](https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/37126862).
 - Added a new API for
 [getCurrentLocation()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/FusedLocationProviderClient#getCurrentLocation(com.google.android.gms.location.CurrentLocationRequest,%20com.google.android.gms.tasks.CancellationToken))
 with additional request options.
 - Added a new API for
 [getLastLocation()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/FusedLocationProviderClient#getLastLocation(com.google.android.gms.location.LastLocationRequest))
 with additional request options.
 - Added new APIs for
 [requestLocationUpdates()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/FusedLocationProviderClient#requestLocationUpdates(com.google.android.gms.location.LocationRequest,%20java.util.concurrent.Executor,%20com.google.android.gms.location.LocationCallback))
 with executor support.
 - Deprecated
 [LocationRequest.PRIORITY\_\*](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/LocationRequest#PRIORITY_BALANCED_POWER_ACCURACY)
 constants in favor of
 [Priority.PRIORITY\_\*](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/Priority#PRIORITY_BALANCED_POWER_ACCURACY)
 constants.
 - Deprecated
 [LocationRequest.setExpirationTime()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/LocationRequest#setExpirationTime(long))
 in favor of
 [LocationRequest.setExpirationDuration()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/LocationRequest#setExpirationDuration(long)).
 - Clarified and added additional guidance throughout the library's
 [reference documentation](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/package-summary).

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-location:20.0.0

## June 1, 2022
- The `play-services-appindex` library is now generally available. This
library is a replacement for the `firebase-appindexing` library and
supports use cases for sharing structured documents as `Indexables`
and `UserActions` with Google Assistant.

For more details on sharing documents with Google Assistant,
see [Push dynamic shortcuts to Assistant](https://developers.google.com/assistant/app/dynamic-shortcuts).

## April 12, 2022
- The latest updates to `play-services-nearby` (v18.1.0) include the following
changes:

 - `BLUETOOTH_ADVERTISE`, `BLUETOOTH_CONNECT` and `BLUETOOTH_SCAN` permissions
 are now required for Nearby Connections from Android S.

 - Added
 [`Payload#setFileName()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/Payload#setFileName(java.lang.String))
 and [`Payload#setParentFolder()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/Payload#setParentFolder(java.lang.String))
 to save the received file with an assigned file name and relative path.

 - Added
 [`VariantOfConcern`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/exposurenotification/VariantOfConcern)
 to allow a Public Health Authority (PHA) to attach a PHA-defined variant of
 concern in exposure notifications.
 For example, a PHA could assign the following definitions:

 - `VariantOfConcernType.type1` as â€œVaccine is effectiveâ€

 - `VariantOfConcernType.type2` as â€œHighly transmissiveâ€

 - `VariantOfConcernType.type3` as â€œHigh severityâ€

 - `VariantOfConcernType.type4` as â€œVaccine breakthroughâ€

 - Deprecated Nearby Message ultrasonic feature.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-nearby:18.1.0

## December 16, 2021
- The latest updates to `play-services-base` and `play-services-tasks` resolve
the [issue](https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/210908929) that can lead to
runtime NPEs ( `NullPointerException`) when handling
`Task ` results in Kotlin code. If you're using any of
the library versions listed in the [December 09, 2021\
release](https://developers.google.com/developers.google.com#december_09_2021), you can avoid the runtime NPEs by explicitly
depending on v18.0.1 of `play-services-base` and `play-services-tasks`. Add
the following to the `dependencies` section of your `build.gradle`:


```
implementation'com.google.android.gms:play-services-base:18.0.1'
implementation'com.google.android.gms:play-services-tasks:18.0.1'
```


In January 2022, we plan to release new versions of the other artifacts
released on [December 09](https://developers.google.com/developers.google.com#december_09_2021) with new `POM` dependencies on
the 18.0.1 versions of `play-services-base` and `play-services-tasks`.

- The latest update to Firebase includes changes to:


 - Firebase Android BoM (Bill of Materials)
 - Firebase SDK for Google Analytics

This Firebase release picks up the latest versions of `play-services-base` and
`play-services-tasks` (v18.0.1) to fix the issue described in the
[December 09, 2021 release](https://developers.google.com/developers.google.com#december_09_2021).

For more information, see the [Firebase Android SDK Release\
Notes](https://firebase.google.com/support/release-notes/android#2021-12-16).

## December 09, 2021
- The latest updates to several libraries include the following change:


 - Strict nullability annotations ( `@NonNull` and `@Nullable`) are being used
 where previously `@RecentlyNonNull` and `@RecentlyNullable` were used. With
 this change, what once caused a nullness warning will now cause an error
 when building Kotlin code or using Java `null` checking frameworks. Similar
 annotation changes will be incrementally rolled out in future releases of
 other `com.google.android.gms` artifacts.

Review the "Artifacts released" section for a full list of affected libraries.

- The latest updates to the `play-services-base`, `play-services-basement`, and
`play-services-tasks` libraries include the strict nullability annotation
changes described above, as well as these additional changes:

 - Removed deprecated fitness constants from
 [Scopes](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/Scopes).
 - Added [`withTimeout()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks#withTimeout(com.google.android.gms.tasks.Task<T>,%20long,%20java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit))
 utilty method to [Tasks](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks)

- The `play-services-maps` client library is now generally available,
supported on Android API Level 19 (Android 4.4, KitKat) and higher.

The release includes a new map renderer that is available for opt-in use,
which provides improved performance and stability, as well as support for
Cloud-based maps styling. For more information about this and other updates,
see the product
[release notes](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-sdk/releases#2021-10-27).

## October 11, 2021
- The `play-services-appset` library is now generally available. This library
is designed to support use cases such as analytics or fraud prevention in a
way that respects user privacy.

This library includes methods to manage app set ID, which is a unique ID that,
on a given device, allows you to correlate usage or actions across a set of
apps owned by your organization. For more information, refer to this [guide](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/app-set-id).

This GA release includes the following updates to the developer preview
version:

 - Renamed multiple client interfaces. For more details, see the
 [`play-services-appset` API reference documentation](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/appset/package-summary).
 - Made the `play-services-appset` library compatible with the upcoming
 developer-scoped app set ID. It's expected that Google Play services will
 add support for the developer-scoped app set ID soon. This capability will
 be released in Google Play services and pushed to users' devices without
 needing to upgrade the version of the `play-services-appset` library.

- The latest update to the `ads-identifier` library includes the declaration of

the permission again in your app manifest to access the advertising ID.
However, if your app shouldn't access the advertising ID, you must remove the
permission using
` `.

## July 28, 2021
- The developer preview release of the `play-services-appset` library is now
available. This library is designed to support use cases such as analytics or
fraud prevention in a way that respects user privacy.

This library includes methods to manage app set ID, which is a unique ID that,
on a given device, allows you to correlate usage or actions across a set of
apps owned by your organization. For more information, refer to this
[guide](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/app-set-id).

- The `ads-identifier` API reference documentation has been updated with
information about an upcoming change to the advertising ID when a user enables
limit ad tracking as well as a requirement on a new Google Play services
permission.

See [`getId()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/ads/identifier/AdvertisingIdClient.Info#getId())
for details. There are no changes to the `ads-identifier` library itself.

## June 16, 2021
- In preparation for enforcing strict nullability, we added `@RecentlyNonNull`
and `@RecentlyNullable` annotations to several SDKs that previously did not
explicitly define nullability. This change will cause warnings on null safety
violations.

This change provides better Kotlin interoperability and better static
null checking for apps that use Java null checking frameworks.

Similar additions of `@RecentlyNonNull` and `@RecentlyNullable` will be
incrementally rolled out in future releases of other `com.google.android.gms`
artifacts.

## June 08, 2021
- The latest updates to `play-services-nearby` (v18.0.0) include the following
changes:

 - Added `@NonNull` and `@Nullable` annotations in the API surface which
 **may break Kotlin apps that did not previously handle `null` values in**
 **a safe way** (see
 [Kotlin documentation about Null-safety](https://kotlinlang.org/docs/java-interop.html#null-safety-and-platform-types)).

 - Changed
 [ConnectionsClient](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionsClient)
 to be an interface instead of an abstract class.

 - Changed
 [ConnectionsClient#MAX\_BYTES\_DATA\_SIZE](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionsClient#MAX_BYTES_DATA_SIZE)
 to be final.

 - Added
 [ConnectionInfo#getAuthenticationDigits()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionInfo#getAuthenticationDigits())
 to get the 4-digit human-readable authentication token that was provided
 to both devices.

 - Added support for sensitive file transfer with
 [Payload#isSensitive()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/Payload#isSensitive())
 and
 [Payload#setSensitive(boolean)](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/Payload#setSensitive(boolean))
 to restrict other APPs from accessing a shared file.

 - Added support for the disruptive upgrade feature. This feature is
 enabled by default. The client can disable it with
 [AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean)](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/AdvertisingOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean))
 and
 [ConnectionOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean)](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/ConnectionOptions.Builder#setDisruptiveUpgrade(boolean)),
 which prevents the originally connected Wi-Fi network from being
 disabled or disconnected during the upgrade progress.

 - Deprecated
 [Payload.File#close()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/Payload.File#close())
 and
 [Payload.Stream#close()](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/nearby/connection/Payload.Stream#close()).
- Updates the Google Mobile Ads Android SDK and Firebase Ads SDK. For more
information, refer to the product
[release notes](https://developers.google.com/admob/android/rel-notes#20.2.0).

 [Package visibility filtering](https://developer.android.com/training/package-visibility)
 on Android 11 (API level 30) and above. After updating to
 `com.google.android.gms:play-services-maps:17.0.1`, you can remove the
 following line from your own `AndroidManifest.xml`:
- The latest update to the Wearable library includes the following changes:


 - Fixed bugs
 - Improved availability for Wearable SDK on devices with Google Play services.

For more information, refer to the
[Wearable release notes](https://developer.android.com/wear/releases).

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-maps:17.0.1
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-wearable:17.1.0

## April 20, 2021
- The latest update to Cast SDK includes changes to:


 - Deleted GameManager and related APIs. They have been deprecated since 2017.
 - Added the [SessionState](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/SessionState) class to the cast client library.
 - Added [CastReasonCodes](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastReasonCodes) to provide detailed explanations of [CastStatusCodes](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/CastStatusCodes). Use the [CastContext#getCastReasonCodeForCastStatusCode(int)](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastContext#getCastReasonCodeForCastStatusCode(int)) method to translate from [CastStatusCodes](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/CastStatusCodes) to [CastReasonCodes](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/cast/framework/CastReasonCodes).
 - Updated the dependencies `com.google.android.datatransport:transport-api` to the latest version.

For more information, see the
[Cast Android Sender SDK Release Notes](https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/release-notes).

## February 18, 2021
- The latest updates to `play-services-location` include the following changes:

 - The Fused Location Provider (FLP) now suppresses initial inaccurate
 locations by default. This behavior allows for improved location accuracy
 while minimally increasing latency. Developers who prefer to have faster
 results instead of more accurate results can call the new
 [`LocationRequest#setWaitForAccurateLocation()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/LocationRequest#setWaitForAccurateLocation(boolean))
 method.

 - Added the
 [`ActivityRecognitionClient#requestSleepSegmentUpdates()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/ActivityRecognitionClient#requestSleepSegmentUpdates(android.app.PendingIntent,%20com.google.android.gms.location.SleepSegmentRequest))
 method to allow apps to register for the
 [Sleep API](https://developers.google.com/location-context/sleep).

## January 25, 2021
- The latest update to `play-services-fido` library includes the following changes:

 - Introduced the initial public beta release of the
 [`SourceDirectTransferClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/sourcedevice/SourceDirectTransferClient) class.
 This class provides a method that turns an Android phone into a FIDO authenticator
 to complete authentication process.

 - Deprecated [`Fido#FIDO2_KEY_RESPONSE_EXTRA`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/Fido#FIDO2_KEY_RESPONSE_EXTRA) and [`Fido#FIDO2_KEY_ERROR_EXTRA`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/Fido#FIDO2_KEY_ERROR_EXTRA).

 - Deprecated [`AuthenticatorAssertionResponse#getKeyHandle()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/AuthenticatorAssertionResponse#getKeyHandle()).

 - Deprecated [`AuthenticatorAttestationResponse#getKeyHandle()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/AuthenticatorAttestationResponse#getKeyHandle()).

 - Introduced [`BrowserRequestOptions#getClientDataHash()`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/api/common/BrowserRequestOptions#getClientDataHash()).

## November 09, 2020
- The latest update to the `play-services-auth` library includes the following
changes:

 - Added a new API client,
 [`CredentialSavingClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/CredentialSavingClient),
 to help you save users' password credentials that can be later used to sign
 them in.

 - Added a new API,
 [`SignInClient#getSignInIntent(GetSignInIntentRequest)`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/auth/api/identity/SignInClient),
 to initiate the Google Sign-In flow when the user taps on the "Sign-In With
 Google" button.
- The latest update to the `play-services-games` library includes the following
changes:

 - Removed the Real-time and Turn-based multiplayer APIs. For more details,
 refer to the
 [documentation](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/9469745).

 - Changed the following clients to interfaces: `AchievementsClient`,
 `EventsClient`, `GamesClient`, `GamesMetadataClient`, `LeaderboardsClient`,
 `PlayersClient`, `SnapshotClient`, and `VideosClient`.

 - Removed the following deprecated GoogleApiClient methods: `getAppId`,
 `getSdkVariant`, and `getSettingsIntent`.

 - Internal updates.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-auth:19.0.0

## October 19, 2020
- The latest updates to the `play-services-base` and `play-services-basement`
libraries include the following changes:

 - Prevents crashes caused when `NoSuchElementException` is occasionally
 thrown when a service is unbound.

 - Throws
 [`GooglePlayServicesIncorrectManifestValueException`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/GooglePlayServicesIncorrectManifestValueException)
 or [`GooglePlayServicesMissingManifestValueException`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/GooglePlayServicesMissingManifestValueException)
 instead of `IllegalStateException` when `AndroidManifest.xml` lacks the
 appropriate metadata tag for using Google Play Services. This may indicate
 an issue with how the app was built.
- The latest update of Google Play services Fitness has the following changes:


 - Write-access now only lets an app read data it has written. To continue
 reading data written by _other_ apps from the Google Fit platform, update
 your code to request read-access scopes for the relevant data types.

 - [Heart rate data](https://developers.google.com/fit/datatypes/health#heart_rate)
 has its own scope.

 - Sleep data has its own scopes and a new data type.
 See [`TYPE_SLEEP_SEGMENT`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fitness/data/DataType#TYPE_SLEEP_SEGMENT)
 and [`SleepStages`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fitness/data/SleepStages).

 - Deprecated
 [`FitnessActivities#SLEEP`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fitness/FitnessActivities#SLEEP)
 and other sleep types. Use the new
 [`SleepStages`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fitness/data/SleepStages)
 instead.

 - When working with the `SessionsClient`, you now need to specify what type of
 session your app needs to access, using the appropriate methods from
 [`FitnessOptions`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fitness/FitnessOptions).


For more information, see the
[Google Fit Release Notes](https://developers.google.com/fit/android/releases#october_19_2020).

- com.google.android.gms:play-services-base:17.5.0

- com.google.android.gms:play-services-fitness:20.0.0

## August 18, 2020
- The latest updates to `play-services-basement`, `play-services-tasks`, and
`play-services-base` include the following changes:

 - In preparation for enforcing strict nullability, we've added
 `@RecentlyNonNull` and `@RecentlyNullable` annotations where the `base` and
 `basement` SDKs previously did not explicitly define nullability. This
 provides better Kotlin interoperability, as well as better static `null`
 checking for anyone using Java `null` checking frameworks. Similar
 additions of `@RecentlyNonNull` and `@RecentlyNullable` will be
 incrementally rolled out in releases of `com.google.android.gms` artifacts.

 - When an API call fails due to a connection issue between the app and Google
 Play services, the failing
 [`ConnectionResult`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/ConnectionResult)
 is now accessible from the
 [`Status`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/api/Status) of
 the [`ApiException`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/api/ApiException).

 - In certain situations where a device does not have valid Google Play
 services, API calls will fail faster instead of waiting for user
 acknowledgement.

 - Added new
 [`GoogleApiAvailability#getErrorDialog`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/GoogleApiAvailability)
 overloads that accept a `Fragment`.

 - Deprecated [`Tasks#call`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/Tasks)
 methods in favor of
 [`TaskCompletionSource`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/tasks/TaskCompletionSource).

 - Internal updates for other Google Play services APIs.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-basement:17.4.0
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-base:17.4.0
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-tasks:17.2.0

## August 17, 2020
- Updates to the `play-services-games` library include the following changes:
 - Added [`loadFriends`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/games/PlayersClient#loadFriends(int,%20boolean)).
 - Added [`getCompareProfileIntent`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/games/PlayersClient#getCompareProfileIntent(java.lang.String)).
 - Added [`getCompareProfileIntentWithAlternativeNameHints`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/games/PlayersClient#getCompareProfileIntentWithAlternativeNameHints(java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String))
 which takes advantage of nicknames to provide more context for the two
 players.
 - Added [`getCurrentPlayer`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/games/PlayersClient#getCurrentPlayer(boolean))
 which retrieves the latest data about the signed-in player.
 - Removed `COLLECTION_SOCIAL`.
 - Added [`COLLECTION_FRIENDS`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/games/leaderboard/LeaderboardVariant#COLLECTION_FRIENDS).
 - Added [`getCurrentPlayerInfo`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/games/Player#getCurrentPlayerInfo())
 which retrieves the properties of the signed-in player.

## April 29, 2020
- The initial release of the `play-services-recaptcha` library is now available.
It includes support for the following two features for both Android phones and
TVs that target API levels 16 and later.

 - [reCAPTCHA Enterprise](https://cloud.google.com/recaptcha-enterprise) APIs,
 which provide clients with a numeric score, indicating the likelihood that a
 user is a real person and not part of an automated attack. For more
 information, refer to this
 [integration guide](https://cloud.google.com/recaptcha-enterprise/docs/instrument-android-apps).

 - reCAPTCHA 2FA APIs, which provide clients with the ability to challenge
 users with an email challenge to confirm their identity. For more
 information, refer to this
 [integration guide](https://cloud.google.com/recaptcha-enterprise/docs/integrate-account-verification).

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-recaptcha:16.0.0

## March 19, 2020
- The latest updates to `play-services-basement`, `play-services-tasks`, and
`play-services-base` include the following changes:


 - Adds ["non-semver-breaking"](https://semver.org/#summary) nullability
 annotations to the API surface

For example,
[`GoogleApiAvailability#makeGooglePlayServicesAvailable`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/common/GoogleApiAvailability#makeGooglePlayServicesAvailable(android.app.Activity))
now returns a `@NonNull Task` so that the Kotlin compiler treats it as
non-null instead of a
[platform type](https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/java-interop.html#null-safety-and-platform-types).
However, the `Activity` parameter passed to it is not marked `@NonNull`
(even though it is effectively non-null) so that this change does not break
Kotlin code that passes in an `Activity?`.

 - Internal updates for other Play services libraries.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-base:17.2.0

- com.google.android.gms:play-services-tasks:17.0.1

## March 10, 2020
- The latest update to `play-services-fido` library includes the following
changes:

 - Deprecated the U2F APIs. U2F API users should migrate to the FIDO2 APIs.
 The U2F API's will be supported through 2020, and will removed in 2021.
 - Exposed new methods in
 [`Fido2ApiClient`](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/fido/fido2/Fido2ApiClient)
 for registration and signing. These methods are more aligned with standard
 - Added support for the
 [`UserVerificationMethod` Extension](https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn/#sctn-uvm-extension)
 in sign requests only. The extension is not supported for registration requests.
 - Added support for the
 [`IsUserVerifyingPlatformAuthenticatorAvailable` method](https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn/#isUserVerifyingPlatformAuthenticatorAvailable).
 - Exposed the `PublicKeyCredential` as a top level response, in accordance
 with the WebAuthn spec.

#### Artifacts released on maven.google.com
- com.google.android.gms:play-services-fido:18.1.0
